Yesterday I did something I had never done in my baseball career: Hit a grand slam. I know what you‚Äôre thinking, ‚ÄúReally, Corp? With those thighs? You‚Äôre so cool and strong I bet you‚Äôve hit 20 of em!‚Äù Yeah, no. I was a pitcher for most of my career. But here‚Äôs the real reason I‚Äôm posting this. I just had my first kiddo a month ago and this was his first game ever. Baseball is a huge part of my life even though I don't talk about it publicly too much. I‚Äôve been playing on this same wood bat team for 10 years. Basically since I left independent minor league ball. It‚Äôs an 18+ adult league and now at the ripe age of 36, I feel old. ‚ÄúThese kids, man!!!‚Äù This season I‚Äôve started off in the tank. Perhaps it‚Äôs that the average age is 10-15 years my junior‚Ä¶ Or maybe I‚Äôm just more tired these days from raising a small screaming potato. I‚Äôve wondered if I‚Äôm washed up (obviously I am). But I just love it too much to quit. Still, I‚Äôm not used to not-dominating. Staring down the barrel of your athletic mortality is scary! Ask any athlete. The doubts had been creeping into my head. But then my wife Becca stepped in. ‚ÄúYou need to hit mid-week if you want to keep up. I‚Äôll go with you.‚Äù Now we go to the batting cages once a week for 30 minutes. She feeds the ball into the machine (4-seam grip of course) and BOOM‚Ä¶ I get jammed by 78mph heaters lol. But yes, my 4-week post-partum wife gets in the batting cage with me and I smoke baseballs back at her. We do this every week now, while little-man gets Grandma time. Part of what made me so scared to have a kid was my fear that I would no longer be able to do the things that made me happy. Things like baseball. I was worried that my life would no longer be mine. And thanks to my wife, her family, and my family, that hasn‚Äôt been the case. I feel so fortunate to have such a strong support system around me. God knows I need it. I'm a prima donna. But, when I think about hitting that home run, I realize what made it special wasn‚Äôt the fact that it was worth 4 runs (though that was tight). It was because my support system was right there behind me: My wife and my son. I mean, literally, they shot the video above! But be it baseball or my weird/wild career path, they‚Äôve always been behind me.
Well, there's a reason they are called `man's best friend` and not `man's best coworker.`

Here's the thing. We never did this for money (SAD is still deep in the red). We never even had a proper marketing plan (oops). And while we didn't make the next Office Space or Glengarry Glen Ross, we made SOMETHING. And now? It's a real movie. Still feels surreal typing that. To everyone who supported this journey, many of you right here on Linkedin- appreciate ya. To Ben who's been there since day one - couldn‚Äôt have done it without you. Biggest lesson? Yesterday I found myself back Stanford University Graduate School of Business 's campus ‚Äînot as the anxiety-ridden student I once was, but as the battle-scarred entertainment veteran I've become. üéì‚ö° When I sat in those seats years ago, I secretly wondered if I'd ever be `good enough` to be invited back. Would my experience be considered worth sharing with students? I wasn't going to be the startup founder with a billion dollar idea, and I certainly wasn't going to be the executive of some publicly traded company. Our panel topic? `The business of creative.` My unofficial subtitle: `How to endure creative heartbreak and still show up tomorrow.` The truth bombs we dropped that weren't in the brochure: --Every idea/project/concept you have becomes sell-job first. --That project you're passionate about? Expect to fight for it for YEARS. --Your brilliant idea will be murdered by millions of anonymous online opinions. --The most successful people aren't necessarily the most talented‚Äîthey're the ones who refused to quit after failure number 89. KEEP WRITING. Watching those polished MBA faces absorb the unfiltered reality of our industry was both terrifying and deeply satisfying. Some looked horrified. Others leaned in. And some will go back to McKinsey. The entertainment business remains the most tumultuous, heartbreaking, and inexplicably rewarding career path I've ever encountered. It's a constant cycle of `I'm not good enough` followed by `Maybe I am` followed by `I definitely am not`‚Äîon endless repeat. Yet here I was, standing where I once sat, proof that surviving the chaos eventually becomes its own kind of credential. At this point in my career I've spoken in front of tens of thousands of people. But no SKO or conference feels quite like getting to go back to your alma mater -- this time facing the student instead of being one. Thank you GSB for the opportunity.

Should you get your MBA or not? Today, LinkedIn dropped their business school rankings and I admit, I didn‚Äôt realize there were other business schools as I‚Äôve never had to scroll past the top spot. Teehee. I‚Äôm kidding. But seriously, the debate on whether or not an MBA is worth your time/money is a big one. I‚Äôll start with saying it‚Äôs a massive privilege to be able to attend graduate school. If you‚Äôre doing a full-time MBA it‚Äôs two years and it‚Äôs very hard to have a full-time job at the same time. Do you need an MBA? Absolutely not. For my salesfolk out there, the MBA could not be less necessary for career advancement. If you can sell, you can sell. Period. There‚Äôs no need to go unless you are considering a pivot out of sales. However, speaking for myself, getting my MBA opened up a ton of opportunities. I was the only salesperson at the school during my two years. After graduation, a lot of my classmates went on to start companies of their own. Suddenly, sales became very very important to them. Who did they call? They called me. I also believe gaining a better understanding of the overall business ecosystem is never a bad thing. How to read a balance sheet, understanding how equity works, how VC works, the process of founding a startup and taking it to IPO... More knowledge makes you more dangerous in your role, regardless of what you do. Again, more of a nice-to-have than a need to have. Last thing I‚Äôll say because this is way too much text‚Ä¶ The most valuable thing I got from business school was the opportunity to be around extremely smart, driven, and ambitious people. They say you are the average of the people you hang out with. Being around so many impressive people made me want to achieve more, and work harder. I felt inspired and compelled to try and do more. To figure things out. Of course many of them are now lifelong friends. For me, getting my MBA was one of the most transformative things I‚Äôve ever done. `Corp how do you write your comedy sketches?` Here's a short breakdown: 1) I always think of Corp Bro in the 3rd person... So first, I come up with a 1 sentence description of the video. It could be `Corp has a rough sales call` or `Corp closes a deal.` In this case we'll use `Corp finds a lucky penny.` 2) Next is figuring out `The Game.` The Game is the main joke or structure that runs through the whole sketch. There are tons of games that can be used and I'll make a separate post about that later. Examples include Parody, Escalation, Topical, Status flip etc. For this video we'll use `Frustration.` 3) Ok so how do we link finding a lucky penny to frustration? Well, what if the penny isn't actually lucky? Maybe it's an unlucky penny. Okay great, so now lets pick 3 unlucky things that happen to Corp? -Coffee machine is broken -Computer freezes -Loses a big deal Now we've included the `rule of 3s` as well as Escalation. All we need is a final scene. 4) Lastly we need to think about `The Button.` ¬†The Button is final line of a sketch. It should not only resolve the sketch and be funny, but place a ‚Äúpretty bow‚Äù on it. With this video, we'll have Corp launch the penny into the ocean... Why? Because screw that penny. But also, to add one more joke, we'll have Corp throw out his arm because he's a washed up athlete. So yeah, there you go! There's your short 20-30 second sketch.
